subject: Re: [junit] testing JSP and Servlets automatically
msgSnippet: ... I have no JSP tag. Poor use of pronouns on my part. Pretend that s you saying what s in points 1, 2 and 3. I apologize for the confusing switch of point of
messageBody:
>So said luca passani on 2003-04-29 --------------------
>
>have you got a link to your JSP tag?

I have no JSP tag. Poor use of pronouns on my part. Pretend that's you saying what's in points 1, 2 and 3. I apologize for the confusing switch of point of view.

>I am not sure I am getting what you wrote...
>Maybe a snippet of code that explains why it works without a servlet
>engine...

I don't have code handy.

If you just want to test that your TagHandler methods work, then just test them like any other normal Java class. That was the key point I wanted to make.

>thank you

You're welcome. I hope that this is clearer.

Take care.

----------------------------
>
>luca
>
>J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
>>What do you want to test?
>>
>>1. My JSP tag processes different calls correctly.
>>2. The framework knows when/how to call my JSP tag handler.
>>3. My JSP tag is registered correctly.
>>
>>There are probably others.
>>
>>To test #1, instantiate your TagHandler and call methods. If you don't
>like that, instantiate a JspProcessor and send it XML fragments.
>>
>>Maybe #2 doesn't make sense. I just wrote it as I was thinking about it.
>>
>>To test #3, check it by hand once then use the Golden Master technique of
>comparing future generations of the XML fragment to the hand-checked
>Golden Master.
>>
>>If you want to test from end to end, look at HTMLUnit.
>>
>>Take care.
>>
>>
>>
>>>So said luca passani on 4/26/2003 --------------------
>>>
>>>Hallo, I am new to the wonderful world of JUnit, but I love the concept.
>>>
>>>I have developed a java library and a simple tag-lib to be used
>>>with tomcat and other application servers. I would like to be able to
>>>unit-test the tags automatically, but the way to do that is not obvious.
>>>
>>>So far, I have used a Perl-based client that requests the pages, but I
>>>think
>>>it would be more elegant if it all could be made automatically from ant
>>>and solely with Java.
>>>
>>>I have noticed that there are a few utils to do that, but I am confused.
>>>Do I need tomcat installed? or not?
>>>What's the bquickest path?
>>>I need to be able to spoof the user-agent string for each request.
>>>Will the existing frameworks allow that?
>>>How do I compare mark-ups without getting those extra whitespaces
>>>in the way? do I need to build my own 'equals' methods using RegExps?
>>>
>>>thank you
>>>
>>>luca
